snippet.textDisplay:
It's a software for playing music. Kinda like Windows Media Player. It was very popular back in the days. Like waaaaay back. Probably around 2005 or so (maybe even earlier). Unlike modern softwares, like iTunes and Spotify, Winamp can only play music that you already have on your pc.

I remember that Winamp was very early with visualizers, something that is not used so much anymore. I still like the visualizers. Sometimes I put on some old psychedelic old progressive rock or some sweet, chill, but psychedelic ambient and then let the visualizer on Winamp run on a big screen. Ah man that's awesome!

snippet.textDisplay:
10,000 B.C. was my favorite time period in the game because it had advanced technology, magic, and had a mystical yet otherworldly feel to it that the rest of the game lacked.  The future was just crapsack, but it had to be in order to give the rest of the game an excuse to continue whereas the other periods were cliche (nothing wrong with that, medieval times are expected to seem and be medieval for example.) 

I kinda liked 65 million BC because of the reptile people, but they died out.  I think 1,000 A.D. is supposed to correlate to the present despite it being a primitive somewhat post-apocalyptic (fall of Rome and all) time in real life.  What I really loved about 1,000 A.D. was the mystics were still alive whereas anything that takes place in contemporary times typically has old mystical races go extinct.  Speaking of which this is what makes Shadowrun kinda cool, elves and dwarfs and such live in a near future cyber-punk world.  1999 would have been a very awesome time to explore at least for a bonus level to uncover extra lore, background, unanswered questions, and such.

Please, don't get me wrong, I loved the first and second, but then it just started to drift off. But what annoyed me the most is that each story seems to be on a different gaming platform (DS, Advance, PS2, PS3, the neighbour's toaster). I like Kingdom Hearts. But only the first two. Good story, music, characters, gameplay.

snippet.textDisplay: Why don't they make games like these anymore...? snippet.textDisplay:
The formulae for the olden RPG adventure games didn't focus on Bad-assness and likeability like they do nowadays but instead chose basic, poignant human interactions, ideas and fancies as their undercurrent. In the case of Crono Trigger:

A young boy takes up the sword and following circumstance, falls into a struggle thats vastness surpasses the hopes that he may succeede; but with the bond of his companions and unwavering courage he just might have what it takes to see his troubles through.

snippet.textDisplay: They really don't make game music like this anymore, and it's more of a sign of the times. Back in 8 and 16-bit eras you had to be clever with your song structure and melody because you could only fit so much on a cartridge and the technology was limited. Now with major symphonic scores (many of which are BLAND, IMO) a lot of games miss the pretty melodic element in their music.
snippet.textOriginal: They really don't make game music like this anymore, and it's more of a sign of the times. Back in 8 and 16-bit eras you had to be clever with your song structure and melody because you could only fit so much on a cartridge and the technology was limited. Now with major symphonic scores (many of which are BLAND, IMO) a lot of games miss the pretty melodic element in their music.

Chrono Trigger was, and still is, one of the most 'perfect' games ever made. Compelling story, fantastic music, enjoyable game play, and a great balance between linear and non-linear action.

snippet.textDisplay: @Alex0Dakaar Amen to that bro. This song instills so much fear into your heart... Even if you've never played the game, you know there's a dark tone to this song. Games nowadays have such bland and miserable compositions that you could just mute the game and play your own music. This is why I'm such a huge fan of the 8 and 16 bit era of gaming. Music meant something back then. It set the tone for each part of the game, and you felt it... Though, CT is absolutely unmatched in terms of good games.

Personally I prefer the past to present in terms of most media not out of nostalgia. I thought that for the longest time, but I got a store a year or two back that sells old games. I buy games for my newer systems, but very rarely and don't find myself coming back often.
I get something for say SNES or N64 or Playstation and I find I can't stop playing it! It's got nothing to do with nostalgia, it's got something to do with quality.

snippet.textDisplay: Graphics aside, Chrono Trigger is still a solid game.  I'd be more than willing to sacrifice graphics in favor of great story telling and a good soundtrack.  Now that's not to say that such games are no longer created, or as entertaining.  There are a few shining examples of more modern games I do enjoy.  It just seems to me that most of the games in the mid to late 90's and early 2000's are the ones I find myself coming back to, since most others now adays are beat once and never play again.

snippet.textDisplay:
Let's not forget the slight undertones of racism that the Enlightened Ones had for the Earthbound Ones. The Dark Ages or, "Antiquity" (blegh, it'll always be Dark Ages in my eyes) really did shift the story abruptly but timely, and put the whole thing into a new perspective. Plus, the whole floating continent thing, to escape the ice cold, many millenia winter the Earthbound Ones had to face...

This entire story is just brilliant. I can't see how anyone could NOT love this game.

snippet.textDisplay:
The port is lacking in new content. Everything that WAS there is still there, and is adapted very nicely to the DS. 

What upsets me is that they are charging full price for a port whose original is nearly 15 years old. In that time, you think the same people who are making Final Fantasy 13 for PS3 could have made a huge amount of new gameplay for this classic SNES game. But nope.. Just an "Arena" which is an uninteractive and boring Pokemon rip, a dungeon, and sprite swap of the final boss. :(
snippet.textOriginal:

If you've beaten the SNES version or PS1 version, it's pretty much the same. The new dungeons and "Arena" mode are lacking. Since you don't have a DS already and I am guessing you have played it before if you are mentioning the DS version, I probably wouldn't.

On the other hand, if you plan on getting a DS for other games too, or you haven't played Chrono Trigger, the DS version is definitely the one you want to play, and the game itself is AMAZING. Just wish Square put more effort in the port.

snippet.textDisplay:
lol i still have it.
oh btw by extracting i mean saving the whole song on HD without disturbing sounds.
heres how to do it:
google for the ZSNES emulator, best emu arounf
google for chrono trigger rom
setup zsnes and load chrono trigger
dont make the song you want start yet
hit F1 in game to make a capture window appear
click "save spc data"
force the song to start (like in sound test)
you will get a message that the file was saved successfully
the file will be in the capture folder

snippet.textDisplay: There's only an extremely short span where you can get the Crono talking ending.  In 12,000BC, you have to watch Schala use her pendant on the door and attempt to do so yourself, and then go back to your time machine and beat the game WITHOUT powering up your pendant.  The ending is Luca and Marle rating all the guys in the game, and Crono running in to tell them to shut up.
